During the investigation of possible to solutions to issue #3664, 3 problems with msvc detection and  another problem with clearing a local rather than global variable were discovered:

items.title: MergeFlags() sometimes modifies its inputs in-place
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
`MergeFlags()` sometime modifies the data pointed to by its arguments in-place.

**Required information**
* Link to SCons Users thread discussing your issue: https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2020-May/008152.html
* Version of SCons: **2.3.1, 2.5.1, 3.1.2**
* Version of Python: **2.7, 3.8**
* Which python distribution if applicable: **- (default install from distro packages)**
* How you installed SCons: **apt-get, portage, manual unpack of release tarballs**
* What Platform are you on?: **Linux - gentoo, Ubuntu 18.04, Ubuntu 20.04**
* How to reproduce your issue?  Please include a small self contained reproducer. Likely a SConstruct should do for most issues.

The absolute smallest example of the problem (that I can come up with) would be something like this:
```python    
flags = {
    'CFLAGS': ['-pipe', '-pthread', '-g'],
    'CXXFLAGS': ['${CFLAGS}', '-std=c++11'],
    'LINKFLAGS': ['-rdynamic', '-pthread'],
    'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF1=1', 'DEF2=2'],
}

print(flags)
env = Environment()
env.MergeFlags(flags)
print(flags)
```
This will print:
```
{'CFLAGS': ['-pipe', '-pthread', '-g'], 'CXXFLAGS': ['${CFLAGS}', '-std=c++11'], 'LINKFLAGS': ['-rdynamic', '-pthread'], 'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF1=1', 'DEF2=2']}
{'CFLAGS': ['-g', '-pthread', '-pipe'], 'CXXFLAGS': ['-std=c++11', '${CFLAGS}'], 'LINKFLAGS': ['-pthread', '-rdynamic'], 'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF2=2', 'DEF1=1']}
```
Notice how the lists are reversed (seemingly) in-place. This appears to happen for any key from the input dict that doesn't exist in the `Environment` at the time `MergeFlags()` is called. We can see this happening by modifying the example above to:
```python
flags = {
    'CFLAGS': ['-pipe', '-pthread', '-g'],
    'CXXFLAGS': ['${CFLAGS}', '-std=c++11'],
    'LINKFLAGS': ['-rdynamic', '-pthread'],
    'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF1=1', 'DEF2=2'],
}

print(flags)
env = Environment()
env['CFLAGS'] = ['-O1']   # set CFLAGS before MergeFlags() gets called
env.MergeFlags(flags)
print(flags)
```
This will now print:
```
{'CFLAGS': ['-pipe', '-pthread', '-g'], 'CXXFLAGS': ['${CFLAGS}', '-std=c++11'], 'LINKFLAGS': ['-rdynamic', '-pthread'], 'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF1=1', 'DEF2=2']}
{'CFLAGS': ['-pipe', '-pthread', '-g'], 'CXXFLAGS': ['-std=c++11', '${CFLAGS}'], 'LINKFLAGS': ['-pthread', '-rdynamic'], 'CPPDEFINES': ['DEF2=2', 'DEF1=1']}
```
You can now see that the list corresponding to the `CFLAGS` key doesn't change now that `env` contains the key when `MergeFlags()` is called. The other lists are still reversed in-place.

A slightly more involved example: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ileonte/scons-bug-maybe/master/SConstruct
Running `scons` repeatedly with the above `SConstruct` will cause incorrect rebuilds of targets that are up-to-date. This happens because `MergeFlags()` modifies the `flags` dict in-place, thus causing the build commands to change because of parameter reordering.
* How you invoke scons (The command line you're using "scons --flags some_arguments"): `scons`

items.title: Users callables can have silent TypeError exceptions
items.body:
Users are able to supply there own callable classes and put them into environment commands as expandable strings. If a user expereinces a TypeError exception in there __call__ method, it will silently be passed over, because scons is catching the TypeError to determine if the callable is not matching the function signature expected.

Example SConstruct:
```
import os
class TestPathIssue(object):
    def __init__(self, thing, makePathsRelative = True, debug = False):
        pass
    def __call__(self, target, source, env, for_signature):
        class FakeClass(object):
            pass
        # simulate the exception
        fake = FakeClass()
        os.path.splitdrive(fake)

env = Environment()
env["TESTCLASS"] = TestPathIssue
env["CCCOM"] = "$CC $_CCCOMCOM $CCFLAGS -o ${TESTCLASS('$TARGET')} -c ${TESTCLASS('$SOURCES')}"

env.Program(target='foo', source='foo.c')
```
results in this failure:

items.title: Programmatic identification of conftest nodes
items.body:
**Describe the Feature**
Programmatic identification of conftest nodes.

Much like the issue reported in #3625, several of our tools work by interposing on emitters or scanners of existing builders. In some cases, the work we want to perform is inappropriate for conftests, either because of the special environment in which they execute, or because the injected behavior is inappropriate for conftests.

For now, we need to do something ugly like 

```
if not "conftest" in str(target[0):
    # Do stuff to non-conftest nodes
```

which is unpleasant and far from foolproof. We think it would be better if there were an attribute or method on Node that would allow us to identify conftest-related nodes directly. Ideally, we could write something better, like:

```
if not target[0].is_conftest():
    # Do stuff to non-conftest nodes
```

Alternatively:

```
if not getattr(target[0].attributes, "is_scons_conftest", False):
    # Do stuff to non-conftest nodes
```

Would it be possible to adorn all nodes used by the SConf subsystem this way? It would make it much easier to handle such nodes differently  when required, without needing to worry that someone is going to introduce a file called "conftest.cpp" next year when they want to write a test for some configuration, not knowing that that name has special meaning to SCons and our tools.

**Required information**
https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2020-April/008072.html

items.title: Programmatically expose all SConstruct/SConscript files used in the build.
items.body:
**Describe the Feature**

This request is driven by work on our Ninja builder for SCons. The Ninja builder needs to declare that the generated build.ninja file have a dependency on SConstruct and all the SConscripts, so that we can detect when the build.ninja file should be regenerated, because the structure of the build as described by SCons has changed.

Currently, we do this by globbing for such files, but this is not a great long term solution. In particular, env.SConscript allows the scripts to be named something other than SConscript, so if we want our Ninja tool to be truly generic, it shouldn't rely on filenames and globbing to do this work.

There are some tricky questions with this one, specifically, with how the phases of SCons execution would populate this vs when the Ninja backend would need access to the list.

Still, if there is still general interest in moving forward with getting the MongoDB Ninja generator upstreamed into SCons, some more robust solution to identifying the SCons files in play will be needed.

**Required information**
* Link to SCons Users thread discussing your issue.
https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2020-April/008072.html

items.title: doc generation with lxml fails on construction variable links
items.body:
When building the generated files which will be used for the manpage and User Guide builds:
```
python3 bin/docs-update-generated.py
```
the result has problems if lxml is in use.  Since SCons has shifted to Python 3 support exclusively, and the bindings for libxslt (which can be used together with the libxml2 bindings instead of lxml) are officially unsupported on Python 3, the use of lxml should be considered the "normal" case.

Specifically, when the Tool documents are generated (`tools.gen` and `tools.mod`), references to SCons construction variables are extracted from the xml files and turned into xml entities that represent links, and will eventually show up as live links in the html output documents.  These references take the form of "Sets" and "Uses" references, like this snip from `gcc.xml`:
```
<sets>
<item>CC</item>
<item>SHCCFLAGS</item>
<item>CCVERSION</item>
</sets>
```
The actual links are generated in `bin/scons-proc.py`, in the `write_gen` method of the `SConsXML` class, like this:
```
            if len(v.sets):
                added = True
                vp = stf.newNode("para")
                s = ['&cv-link-%s;' % x for x in v.sets]
                stf.setText(vp, 'Sets:  ' + ', '.join(s) + '.')
                stf.appendNode(vl, vp)
            if len(v.uses):
                added = True
                vp = stf.newNode("para")
                u = ['&cv-link-%s;' % x for x in v.uses]
                stf.setText(vp, 'Uses:  ' + ', '.join(u) + '.')
                stf.appendNode(vl, vp)
```
So the gcc entry should come out like this:
```
<para>Sets:  &cv-link-CC;, &cv-link-CCVERSION;, &cv-link-SHCCFLAGS;.</para>
```
But when lxml is in use, the `&` is coverted to a character entity so we get this, which is broken:
```
<para>Sets:  &cv-link-CC;, &cv-link-CCVERSION;, &cv-link-SHCCFLAGS;.</para>
```
The code above is apparently the only place we write strings to nodes that contain what look like entities (`&foo;`) so it seems to be the only place that suffers from this XML escaping problem.

At the moment a simple post-processing step (e.g. run `sed` to turn `&cv-` back into `&cv-`) can be used (no such workaround is integrated into the build, has been done manually), but we need to figure out how to fix this "more correctly". There is an entirely different definition of the `TreeFactory` class in `bin/SConsDoc.py` for the lxml case vs. the libxml2 case, presumably this is where something could happen, but I can't see what, yet.

items.title: Drop use of the -tt flag in testing (or make version-dependent)
items.body:
In CPython 2.x, we see this command-line flag (https://docs.python.org/2.7/using/cmdline.html):

> -t
> Issue a warning when a source file mixes tabs and spaces for indentation in a way that makes it depend on the worth of a tab expressed in spaces. Issue an error when the option is given twice (-tt).

This flag is absent in CPython 3.x, where instead this paragraph has been added in the language definition:

> Indentation is rejected as inconsistent if a source file mixes tabs and spaces in a way that makes the meaning dependent on the worth of a tab in spaces; a TabError is raised in that case.

That is, the effect of the `-tt` flag is now interpreter behavior and no flag is needed.  CPython 3 does not complain if it is supplied, but PyPy 3 errors out with an unknown flag.  

Thus I would propose we root out the use of -tt in the testing harness, or alternatively (but perhaps less desirably given that SCons probably won't be supporting Py2.x for that much longer) supply the flag in a version-specific manner.

This issue should be attached to the PyPy support project as it completely prevents running the testsuite with PyPy 3.

items.body:
* Version of SCons
3.0.1
* Version of Python
Any

* What Platform are you on? (Linux/Windows and which version)
MacOS

Initially reported by MacPorts Ryan Schmidt

Discussions include:
- http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/serf-dev/201805.mbox/%3c334427a4-3e1e-6445-2f81-d3dbe8ec30b6@apache.org%3e
- https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2018-May/006918.html
- https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2018-October/007328.html

# Issue 
Currently there is no support for SHLIBVERSION on mac. It was likely dropped around 2.4.1 when the current version of SHLIBVERSION logic was rolled out.

MacPorts Ticket: https://trac.macports.org/ticket/50854

Suggested implementation by @acmorrow

> 
> My recommendation would be to not attempt to automatically provide values for -compatibility_version and -current_version, but to provide variables that allow users to set them. If you did want something that mapped SHLIBVERSION=x.y.z to -current_version=y.z -compat_version=y.0 or something (or the +1 variants of that), I think you could do it with generator functions that would parse SHLIBVERSION.
> 
```
# No flags passed for -current_version or -compat_version
 env.SharedLibrary(..., SHLIBVERSION=1.2.3, ...)
 
# User sets explicitly, links with -Wl,-current_version=7.1 -Wl,-compatibility_version=7.0
 env.SharedLibrary(..., SHLIBVERSION=1.2.3, APPLELINK_CURRENT_VERSION=7.1,  APPLELINK_COMPATIBILITY_VERSION=7.0)
 
# User programmatically describes how SHLIBVERSION maps to values for compat/current.

 def currentVersionFromSoVersion(source, target, env, for_signature):
     return env['SHLIBVERSION'].split(.)[1:]
 
 def compatVersionFromSoVersion(source, target, env, for_signature):
     return env['SHLIBVERSION'].split(.)[1] + ".0"
 
 env['APPLELINK_CURRENT_VERSION'] = currentVersionFromSoVersion
 env['APPLELINK_COMPATIBILITY_VERSION'] = compatVersionFromSoVersion
 
# Links as -Wl,current_version=2.3 -Wl,compat_version=2.0
 env.SharedLibrary(..., SHLIBVERSION=1.2.3, ...)
 
# Something like that? Would currentVersionFromSoVersion be able to see the SHLIBVERSION set in the following:
 
 env.SharedLibrary(
     SHLIBVERSION=1.2.3,
     APPLELINK_CURRENT_VERSION=currentVersionFromSoVersion
 )
```
> 
> You could also add some validation for the rules for current_version and compatibility_version in whatever piece of applelink.py ends up doing the expansion of APPLELINK_CURRENT_VERSION and APPLELINK_COMPATIBILITY_VERSION.

items.title: packaging tests fail on newer rpm
items.body:
A set of packaging tests which build rpm packages - obviously due to availability only run on systems which have an `rpm`/`rpmbuild` command - fail on "new" rpm. Fail as in the `rpmbuild` itself fails to complete. There are multiple issues.

    test/packaging/option--package-type.py
    test/packaging/rpm/cleanup.py
    test/packaging/rpm/internationalization.py
    test/packaging/rpm/multipackage.py
    test/packaging/rpm/package.py
    test/packaging/rpm/tagging.py

The error looks like this:

    error: Empty %files file /tmp/testcmd.247674.0oeSTZ/rpmtemp/BUILD/foo-1.2.3/debugsourcefiles.list

I don't have a precise definition for "new", but certainly current Fedora instances (26/27/28) do this and now I recognize what is happening I know it goes back a lot further than that.  Package building in the Red Hat / Fedora / Centos world wants to build separate debug support packages by default now, and runs, behind the scenes, a script which tries to extract things, building file lists which are used, again behind the scenes, in building additional packages besides ones you thought you were asking for (that is, beyond the base package name plus any subpackages you define with `%package` directives - the specfile has no hint these extra packages are being built). All this is stuff the packaging tests in scons do not expect.  `debugsourcefiles.list`?  How to deal with that?

So you can turn off debug building. I am not clear if it is the right thing to do unconditionally; certainly the tests as written need to do so, or else be reworked a lot, risking not working on systems which do not have this rpm implementation. It could be done conditionally - other rpm settings exist in defined construction environment variables, one could add another to control debug-package generation, letting the tests avoid it but packages actually being built which might expect these extra packages can leave it undisturbed.

More fun - packages may also have unexpected contents. In the test code, the generated specfile contains a deduced files section:

    %files
    %defattr (-,root,root)
     /bin/main
(the initial space is probably a bug in the code which deduces the files). But running `rpm -qlp` on the package generated during the same test shows these contents:

    $ rpm -qlp ./foo-1.2.3-0.x86_64.rpm
    /bin/main
    /usr/lib/.build-id
    /usr/lib/.build-id/05
    /usr/lib/.build-id/05/3cbb2cec927c20f70df854a21b3cf1d17e4c34

so the test which tries an exact match with what has been generated in scons, namely the single line `"/bin/main"` still fails, even after you make fixes to make the package build.  There is a different test routine to make sure it contains that line, but could contain other things - the test can easily use this routine.

An additional problem is that there is code purporting to allow specifying an alternate build architecture, by setting a value for the (documented) `ARCHITECTURE` key in the construction envirionment. While this value is used in constructing the target filename, it is never actually given to `rpmbuild` - it has to either be a command-line argument `--target ARCHITECTURE`, or added as a line `BuildArch: ARCHITECTURE` in the specfile, scons does neither.   This is an actual scons problem, not a test problem; probably the alternate-architecture stuff (with 'noarch' being the interesting one) has only lightly been exercised.

This issue is scons version-agnostic (confirmed on 3.0.1) and python version-agnostic (confirmed on 2.7 and 3.6); not certain the rpm-build version but definitely a problem on 4.14 and the Fedora versions mentioned.

Reproducer: given a suitable Linux host such as Fedora 27, just run one of the tests above:

    python runtest.py test/packaging/rpm/package.py

items.title: SConscript(non-existing-file) is only a warning
items.body:
Maling list discussion: see https://pairlist4.pair.net/pipermail/scons-users/2018-July/007111.html
TL;DR: calling SConscript() with a file that does not exist is a warning, not an error.
It is possible to argue that the current behavior is correct just as it is that it is wrong.  Life would be better if at least there is a way for a user to make sure they get hit with a big hammer if they want, if they leave something out, for example, when running a test suite.
Some approaches:

- adding a warning-control framework to the warning framework would allow some or all of the warnings to be classified as errors. 
    - Syntax in the style of gcc, `--Werror=`, is one possibility
    - Syntax like the existing scons `--warn=` (pretty similar) is another
    - the Python warnings module syntax provides another possible option (something like `
warnings.filterwarnings("error")` in code, with some syntax for commandline). This is more flexible than just warning=>error, it provides setting actions from the set (default, error, ignore, always, module, once), but would require reworking the scons warnings framework to match the Python one.
- modify the SConscript call to take a keyword argument, such as must_exist, which controls whether the call fails if the file is missing or not.  This does not affect any other warnings, and could have a suitable deprecation message and deprectation period with an option to switch to the new behavior immediately.  PR #3154 proposes this approach.

I'm just filing this issue as a heads-up for an issue that will probably arise when you begin testing on Python 3.7.
